title: Pseudo-Voigt Function — pseudo_voigt
text: Pseudo-Voigt function approximation Voigt function. defined linear combination Gaussian Lorentzian functions, weighted mixing parameter \(\eta\) (eta) determines relative contribution component.

title: Pseudo-Voigt Function — pseudo_voigt
code: pseudo_voigt(x, y0, xc, wG, wL, A, eta = NULL)

title: Pseudo-Voigt Function — pseudo_voigt
text: x numeric vector representing independent variable (e.g., wavelength frequency). y0 numeric value specifying baseline offset. xc numeric value representing center peak. wG numeric value specifying Gaussian full width half maximum (FWHM). wL numeric value specifying Lorentzian FWHM. numeric value representing peak area. eta numeric value 0 1, representing mixing parameter. eta = NULL (default), mixing parameter approximated polynomial function wG wL. approximation (accuracy 1%), proposed Ida et al. (2000), provides analytical expression mixing parameter based relative FWHM Gaussian Lorentzian components. polynomial approximation useful precise value eta unknown.

title: Pseudo-Voigt Function — pseudo_voigt
text: numeric vector length x, containing computed pseudo-Voigt function values. eta = NULL, function returns list following components: $y: numeric vector length x, containing computed pseudo-Voigt function values using approximated mixing parameter. $eta: approximate mixing parameter calculated using polynomial approximation based wG wL values.

title: Pseudo-Voigt Function — pseudo_voigt
text: Pseudo-Voigt function given : $$y = y_0 + \cdot [ \eta \cdot L(x, x_c, w_L) + (1 - \eta) \cdot G(x, x_c, w_G)]$$ : \(\) peak area \(y_0\) baseline offset \(G(x, x_c, w_G)\) Gaussian component center \(x_c\) full width half maximum \(w_G\) \(L(x, x_c, w_G)\) Lorentzian component center \(x_c\) full width half maximum \(w_L\) \(\eta\) mixing parameter, \(0 \leq \eta \leq 1\). mixing parameter \(\eta\) allows pseudo-Voigt function describe wide range line shapes, pure Gaussian (\(\eta = 0\)) pure Lorentzian (\(\eta = 1\)), various intermediate shapes . Olivero Longbothum (1977) approximation, subsequent refinements (Belafhal 2000; Zdunkowski et al. 2007), offer efficient accurate way (accuracy 0.02%) estimate half-width Voigt line, given : $$w_v = \frac{1}{2} \cdot [c_1 \cdot w_L + \sqrt(c_2 \cdot w_L^2 + 4 \cdot w_G^2)]$$ \(c_1 = 1.0692\), \(c_2 = 0.86639\)

title: Pseudo-Voigt Function — pseudo_voigt
text: Zdunkowski, W., Trautmann, T., Bott, ., (2007). Radiation Atmosphere — Course Theoretical Meteorology. Cambridge University Press. Belafhal, ., (2000). shape spectral lines: Widths equivalent widths Voigt profile. Opt. Commun., 177(1-6):111–118. Olivero, J., Longbothum, R., (1977). Empirical fits Voigt line width: brief review. J. Quant. Spectrosc. Radiat. Transfer, 17(2):233–236. Ida, T., Ando, M., Toraya, H., (2000). Extended pseudo-Voigt function approximating Voigt profile. Journal Applied Crystallography. 33(6):1311–1316.

title: Pseudo-Voigt Function — pseudo_voigt
code: x <- seq(-2, 2, length.out = 100) y1 <- pseudo_voigt(x, y0 = 0, xc = 0, wG = 1, wL = 0.5, A = 2, eta = 0) y2 <- pseudo_voigt(x, y0 = 0, xc = 0, wG = 1, wL = 0.5, A = 2, eta = 0.5) y3 <- pseudo_voigt(x, y0 = 0, xc = 0, wG = 1, wL = 0.5, A = 2, eta = 1) y4 <- pseudo_voigt(x, y0 = 0, xc = 0, wG = 1, wL = 0.5, A = 2) plot(x, y1, type = "l", col = "red", main = "Pseudo-Voigt Profile", ylim = c(0, 5.5)) lines(x, y2, col = "blue") lines(x, y3, col = "green") lines(x, y4$y, col = "black") legend("topright", legend = c("eta = 1", "eta = 0.5", "eta = 0", "eta = NULL"), col = c("red", "blue", "green", "black"), lty = 1)   # The approximated mixing parameter: y4$eta #> [1] 0.4647941

title: Classical or Robust Z-Score — zscore
text: Z-scores useful comparing data points different distributions dimensionless standardized. positive z-score indicates data point mean (median robust approach), negative z-score indicates data point mean (median). One common rule detect outliers using z-scores "three-sigma rule", data points absolute z-score greater 3 (|z| > 3) can considered potential outliers, fall outside range covers 99.7% data points normal distribution. (Note cutoff |z| > 2.5 also often used).
